titleInfo.title: Rising From the Ashes Oral Histories

mods.abstract: Rising from the Ashes documents the immediate and ongoing impacts of the 2016 Chimney Tops 2 wildfires, one of the largest natural disasters in Tennessee history. The fires began on November 23, 2016 in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park and caused fourteen deaths, injuries to more than 200 individuals, and the evacuation of thousands of people. Rising from the Ashes has collected nearly 140 audio and video interviews with individuals who were impacted by or involved in the wildfires. The oral histories include interviews with those who lost homes and businesses, first responders, recovery specialists and representatives from charitable and volunteer organizations, government officials, fire and forestry experts, scientists, artists, lawyers, journalists, clergy, mental health professionals, educators, and members of the Latinx community. More than 40 of the interviews were recorded by the Anna Porter Public Library in the months following the wildfires and were donated to UT Libraries as part of this project.

subject.geographic: Arrowmont School of Arts and Crafts

mods.note: The Rising from the Ashes Oral History Project collects personal accounts of the Chimney Tops 2 Wildfires of 2016, and The University of Tennessee holds no liability for statements made in the recordings. These accounts reflect the opinions of the narrators, and thus they are subjective and should not be considered verified or comprehensive. Oral history interviews may be used alongside other primary and secondary source materials to gain a fuller understanding of historical events.
